sen.j: 三穂津姫（みほつひめ）は、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)である。
sen.e: "Mihotsu-hime" is a god (Shinto) appearing in a Japanese myth.
"Mihotsu-hime" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.
"Mihotsu-hime" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.

sen.j: タカミムスビの娘で、大物主あるいは大国主の后。
sen.e: She is the daughter of Takamimusubi no kami, and the empress of Omononushi or Okuninushi.
She is the daughter of Takamimusubi no kami, and the empress of Omononushi or Okuninushi.
She is the daughter of Takamimusubi no kami, and the empress of Omononushi or Okuninushi.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』の葦原中国平定の場面の第二の一書にのみ登場する。
sen.e: She appears only in one document in the second part of the scene on Ashihara no Nakatsukuniheitei in the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
She appears only in one document in the second part of the scene of Ashihara no Nakatsukuniheitei in the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
She appears only in one document in the second part of the scene of Ashihara no Nakatsukuniheitei in the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 大己貴神（大国主）が国譲りを決め、幽界に隠れた後、高皇産霊尊が大物主神（大国主の荒魂・和魂）に対し「もしお前が国津神を妻とするなら、まだお前は心を許していないのだろう。
sen.e: After Onamuchi no kami (Okuninushi) decided on moving over the province and hid in the realm of the dead, Takamimusubi no kami said to Omononushi no kami (Aramitama and Nigimitama of Okuninushi), 'If you are taking Kunitsu kami as your wife, it means you haven't surrendered your soul yet.

After Onamuchi no kami (Okuninushi) decided on moving over to the province and hid in the realm of the dead, Takamimusubi no kami said to Omononushi no kami (Aramitama and Nigimitama of Okuninushi), 'If you are taking Kunitsu kami as your wife, it means you haven't surrendered your soul yet.

After Onamuchi no kami (Okuninushi) decided on moving over to the province and hid in the realm of the dead, Takamimusubi no kami said to Omononushi no kami (Aramitama and Nigimitama of Okuninushi), 'If you are taking Kunitsu kami as your wife, it means you haven't surrendered your soul yet.

sen.j: 私の娘の三穂津姫を妻とし、八十万神を率いて永遠に皇孫のためにお護りせよ」と詔した。
sen.e: Take my daughter, Mihotsu-hime, as your wife, and lead the Yaoyorozu no kami to eternally surrender it to imperial descendants.
Take my daughter, Mihotsu-hime, as your wife, and lead the Yaoyorozu no kami to eternally surrender your soul to the imperial descendants.
sen.cmt: "the" added, changed "it" to "soul", but not sure if this is accurate
sen.e: Take my daughter, Mihotsu-hime, as your wife, and lead the Yaoyorozu no kami to eternally surrender your soul to the imperial descendants.

sen.j: ミホツヒメの「ツ」は「の」の意味で、ミホの女神という意味になる。
sen.e: The 'tsu' in Mihotsu-hime means 'no,' and it means goddess of Miho.
The 'tsu' in Mihotsu-hime means 'no,' and it means goddess of Miho.
The 'tsu' in Mihotsu-hime means 'no,' and it means goddess of Miho.

sen.j: 出雲の美保神社（島根県松江市）で大国主神の子の事代主とともに祀られている。
sen.e: She is enshrined in the Miho-jinja Shrine in Izumo Province (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture), together with Kotoshironushi, who is the child of Okuninushi no kami.
She is enshrined in the Miho-jinja Shrine in Izumo Province (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture), together with Kotoshironushi, who is the child of Okuninushi no kami.
She is enshrined in the Miho-jinja Shrine in Izumo Province (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture), together with Kotoshironushi, who is the child of Okuninushi no kami.

sen.j: 丹波の出雲大神宮（京都府亀岡市）では大国主神とともに主祭神となっており、大国主神の后とされている。
sen.e: At the Izumo-daijingu Shrine (Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture), she is the main goddess worshipped along with Okuninushi no kami, and is considered the empress of Okuninushi no kami.
At the Izumo-daijingu Shrine (Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture), she is the main goddess worshipped along with Okuninushi no kami, and is considered the empress of Okuninushi no kami.
At the Izumo-daijingu Shrine in Tanba (Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture), she is the main goddess worshipped along with Okuninushi no kami, and is considered the empress of Okuninushi no kami.

sen.j: 村屋坐弥冨都比売神社（奈良県磯城郡田原本町）では大物主神とともに主祭神となっており、大物主神の后とされている。
sen.e: At the Murayaniimasumifutsuhime-jinja Shrine (Tawaramoto-cho, Shiki-gun, Nara Prefecture), she is the main goddess worshipped along with Omononushi no kami, and is considered the empress of Omononushi no kami.

At the Murayaniimasumifutsuhime-jinja Shrine (Tawaramoto-cho, Shiki-gun, Nara Prefecture), she is the main goddess worshipped along with Omononushi no kami, and is considered the empress of Omononushi no kami.
